awd_abstract_narration:
A dynamo is a device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy. It does this by moving an electrical conductor across a magnetic field. This induces an electrical current which creates its own induced magnetic field. The dynamo becomes self-excited when the induced and inducing magnetic fields are the same. A similar self-excited process creates Earth's magnetic field.  The associated electric currents flow in the Earth's core, a nearly spherical mass of liquid iron, of radius 2,200 miles, surrounding the Earth's center. Because of this conducting fluid's motion, the Earth's core is a gigantic electric generator, called 'the geodynamo'. A dynamo also needs a power source to maintain its motion and production of electricity despite heat losses through electrical resistance. For the geodynamo the power source is thought to be due to the buoyancy of density differences in the core. The power is expended not only in maintaining the magnetic field but also in overcoming the frictional forces opposing the fluid motion. Current numerical simulations assume that the frictional energy losses are comparable with those from electrical resistance, but it is generally agreed that in reality they are very much less.  A dynamo that ignores frictional losses is termed magnetostrophic, and the investigators have recently revived an old idea of the plasma physicist, Bryan Taylor, that has led them to a new numerical procedure through which they have already derived two-dimensional solutions of the magnetostrophic equations. The investigators believe that, when they have made the solutions three-dimensional (a complicated step), they will become the new paradigm for future simulations of magnetic field creation and lead to a better understanding of how the Earth and other planets create their magnetism.

The north-seeking property of the magnetic compass needle shows that the Coriolis force strongly influences core motion. This force is balanced primarily by buoyancy and the Lorentz force, which is the force exerted on a current-carrying conductor by the magnetic field. Taylor showed in 1953 how the resulting simplified dynamical balance could be achieved, so determining the fluid velocity as a functional of the magnetic field.  To close the regenerative loop, it is necessary to determine the magnetic field from the fluid velocity, but that is the well-known and well-understood kinematic dynamo process. The way ahead seemed simple in 1953 but all the determined attempts made since then to implement Taylor's suggestion failed, prior to that of the investigating team this year.  The model was greatly simplified by assuming symmetry with respect to the Earth's rotation axis.  The well-known alpha-effect was invoked as the power source. This also made Cowling's theorem, that otherwise would have ruled out axisymmetric solutions, inapplicable.  To convince the dynamo community that this success is meaningful, the team plans to abandon axisymmetry, remove the alpha-effect, and rely on buoyancy to supply the required power.  The investigators believe that their results will be an eye-opener for the dynamo community, and will become the basis for models of naturally-occurring dynamos in planets and stars that are more realistic than today's simulations which assume a viscous friction that is very much too large.

Report on NSF grant EAR1417031

THREE-DIMENSIONAL MAGNETOSTROPHIC DYNAMOS

It is generally agreed that most magnetic elds in the Universe are maintained by self-excited

dynamo action, the same process that creates electricity for domestic and industrial use. Naturally-

occuring sources of electric current are usually localized in volumes of electrically-conducting plasma

or uid, but the magnetic elds that inevitably accompany the ow of electricity escape those

volumes and are observed far outside them. For example, the geomagnetic eld is seen at and beyond

Earth's surface but is created by electric currents owing in Earth's liquid core, 2900km beneath

our feet. The electrical resistance of core uid would cause the currents and accompanying magnetic

elds to disappear in roughly 50,000 years were it not for the dynamo mechanism maintaining them.

In short, they are sustained by a self-excitation mechanism in which the electric currents induced

when an electrical conductor passes across a magnetic eld is the same electrical current producing

that magnetic eld. This self-exciting process, discovered by Werner von Siemens in the 1850s, is

today universally employed by the industrial dynamos in power stations that create electricity for

domestic and commercial use. Geodynamo theory is a part of a study of dynamos in the Universe

that create and maintain magnetic elds in the same way.

A relevant parameter in core MHD is the Ekman number, E, which quanties the relative

strength of the viscous and rotational (Coriolis) forces acting on the ow of the electrically-

conducting, iron-rich uid in Earth's core. Using standard numerical techniques, Glatzmaier and

Roberts (1995a,b, 1996) created three-dimensional dynamo models, the rst of many. We call

them, `Today's models'. The demands of numerical stability limit today's models to E > 10􀀀6.

For Earth's core, however, E  10􀀀15. A few modelers believe E = 10􀀀6 is small enough to repre-

sent core dynamics for E = 10􀀀15 adequately, but many others think today's models are irrelevant

not only to the Earth but also to planets, satellites and stars.

In 1963 the plasma physicist, Bryan Taylor, observed that so-called magnetostrophic (`MS')

dynamos, which assume E = 0, are not restricted by the demands of numerical stability. Although

Taylor (1963) described in detail how MS dynamos could be simulated, he as unable to provide

numerical conrmation. There were several determined but unsuccessful attempts to implement

his idea, and interest subsided after the advent of today's models in 1995. Dissatisfaction with the

large E of today's models, has since led to a revival of the MS dynamo. During our tenure of this

grant, we scored a major success: creation of the rst successful MS dynamo (Wu & Roberts 2015).

It is of simple `mean eld' type; others (e.g., Li et al. 2018) have now produced similar MS models.

Currently, we are adding geophysically realism by recognizing that uid motions in Earth's core

are convectively driven.

References

Glatzmaier, G.A. and Roberts, P.H., A threedimensional convective dynamo solution with rotating

and nitely conducting inner core and mantle, Phys. Earth Planet. Inter., 1995a, 91, 6375.

Glatzmaier G.A. and Roberts P.H., A three-dimensional self-consistent computer simulation of a

geomagnetic eld reversal, Nature, 1995b, 377, 203209.

Glatzmaier, G.A. and Roberts, P.H., An anelastic evolutionary geodynamo simulation driven by

compositional and thermal convection, Physica D, 1996, 97, 81{94.

Li, K., Jackson, A. and Livermore, P.W., Taylor state dynamos found by optimal control: axisym-

metric examples. J. Fluid Mech., 2018, 853, 647{697.

Taylor, J.B., The magnetohydrodynamics of a rotating uid and the Earth's dynamo problem.

Proc. R. Soc. Lond., 1963, A274, 274{283.

Wu, C.-C. and Roberts, P.H., On magnetostrophic mean-eld solutions of the geodynamo equations,

Geophys. Astrophys. Fluid Dynam., 2015, 109, 84{110.
